_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 Corporate Statement
The Facility operates a hazardous waste treatment and storage facility (TSDF) in accordance with a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) hazardous waste license issued by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (DEP).  The Facility strives to conduct its business and operations in strict conformity with all applicable laws, and in a safe and responsible manner.  The Facility has always placed the highest priority on the health and safety of its employees and members of the community in which it operates.
The Facility is subject to the provisions of the Accidental Release Prevention requirements because regulated toxic and flammable liquids are present in quantities which, on occasion, exceed the regulatory thresholds for these substances. Accordingly, the Facility has prepared a Risk Management Plan.
The Facility 's accidental release prevention program involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The Facility is designed, constructed, inspected, maintained and operated in a manner so as to minimize the risk of exposure to employees and the public to hazardous materials managed at the site, and in conformity with all governmental regulations.
The Facility has a comprehensive Inspection Plan, which requires daily, weekly, monthly, and annual inspections of its processes, equipment and management practices.
The Facility maintains a Contingency Plan, which prescribes procedures to be followed in the event of a fire or release at the facility.  The Contingency Plan includes procedures for notifying local, state and federal emergency response officials of incidents, and specifies arrangements made with emergency responders to ensure an effective response in the event of an emergency.
The Facility has a training program which ensures that each employee receives the training necessary to enable him/her to safely and effectively carry out his/her job responsibilities.  Included in

the facility training plan are training modules which instruct employees on the hazards of the regulated substances stored at the site, the procedures for evacuation from the facility, procedures for responding to releases, and procedures for notification of incidents to both facility personnel and offsite emergency responders.  In addition to the initial training that all employees receive, each employee receives refresher training on an annual basis.
2.0 Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The FacilityÂ¿s release prevention program and emergency response procedures have been developed in accordance with the EPA requirements for hazardous waste facilities described in the federal regulations 40 CFR 264 Subpart C and Subpart D. In addition, these requirements have been adopted by the State of Florida and incorporated by the Florida DEP in a facility permit #64247-HO-010 issued Sept 19, 2007.
Release prevention policies include: design and operation of the facility; communication equipment; testing and maintenance of equipment; access to communication and alarm systems; aisle space requirements and arrangements with local authorities. 
Emergency response policies include: designation of emergency coordinators; detailed emergency action procedures including notification of local authorities; lists of emergency response equipment; emergency phone numbers; evacuation procedures and reporting requirements.
3.0 Description of the Facility and Regulated Substances 
The Facility is a commercial hazardous waste management facility engaged in the storing and bulking of hazardous waste regulated under RCRA.  Hazardous and non hazardous waste is stored in containers in enclosed warehouses and in outdoor tanks. The facility has the potential to store chloroform  and butane, which are regulated RMP chemicals, in quantities greater than the threshold planning quantity of 20,000 and 10,000 pounds respectively.
Off-specification or partially used aerosol spra

y cans (containing butane) and butane lighters are received from customers in 55-gallon drums. The aerosol cans are repackaged into cubic yard boxes with a maximum  of 700 pounds per box. Drums and cubic yard boxes are transported to and from the facility by truck. The material is stored in the North Container Storage Building in Department of Transportation (DOT) approved containers for a time period that generally does not exceed 90 days. The butane containing materials are shipped out of the facility to another Clean Harbors waste management facility for ultimate disposal (incineration). The maximum quantity of butane that can be stored at the facility is 11,600 pounds. 

Waste chloroform mixtures (50 - 100% chloroform) are received from customers in 55-gallon drums and 5,000-gallon tank trucks. Drums are accumulated in the warehouses and are shipped off-site in full truck loads to a sister Clean Harbors facility for incineration. Material is pumped from tank trucks into one of the ten (10); 8,800-gallon lean water tanks located in the product storage area tank farm. When sufficient quantities have accumulated, the chloroform mixture is pumped out of the storage tanks into transport tankers and transported to another Clean Harbors waste management facility for ultimate disposal (incineration). The maximum quantity of chloroform that can be stored at the facility is 107,500 pounds.
4.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention 
The EPA risk management regulations identify three levels of requirements.  Program Level 2 applies to the Facility, because this facility is not subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Process Safety Management program and does not qualify for Program Level 1.  The facility has procedures in place to prevent and mitigate potential releases of toxic and flammable substances including chloroform and butane.  These procedures are detailed in the Facility's RCRA Part B hazardous

employee safety and health and on protection of the community from all plant-induced environmental conditions.  An emergency response plan has been developed which prescribes emergency procedures, which the facility will implement in the event of a release or fire at the facility.
The FacilityÂ¿s Emergency Response Plan is identified as the facility Contingency Plan.  The purpose of this plan is to describe both the hazards associated with the management of waste materials at the facility and the steps that will be taken to minimize the risk associated with each hazard.  By ensuring that proper preventative measures are taken at all times and by providing for emergency response procedures to be followed in the event of any unexpected occurrence(s), the Facility intends to operate its facility in a manner that does not pose a significant threat to public health, safety or welfare of the environment.  The Facility's record in this regard has been exceptional and its overall contribution to the protection of human health and the environment far surpasses the risks associated with the type of activities performed at the facility.
The specific elements of The Facility's Contingency Plan are discussed in Section 6.0 of this RMP.
7.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The facility has organized its management system to effectively address all hazards and potential risks. Thorough accident investigation and personnel training are necessary to support continual improvement in the facility safety program.  The Facility's accident investigation procedure and training plan are designed to incorporate new technology improvement in safety as well as lessons learned from accidents. This information is shared on a national level between Environmental Health and Safety (EH&S) professionals and company management to increase awareness and improve safety procedures.  
Current information about the safe handling of all chemicals present at the facility is available to employees, and can

be readily interpreted by emergency response team staff and the Facility Emergency Coordinators when questions arise from public safety officials regarding potential risks to the community.  All of these features of the RMP and the integrated risk management program at this site lead to operations that meet or exceed the state and federal regulatory requirements applicable to the facility's operations.
